Module kivakit.validation
Package com.telenav.kivakit.validation

Class BaseValidator

java.lang.Object
com.telenav.kivakit.validation.BaseValidator
All Implemented Interfaces:
Validator
Direct Known Subclasses:
ArgumentListValidator, SwitchListValidator
public abstract class BaseValidator extends Object implements Validator
A base implementation of Validator that provides convenience methods for reporting validation issues:

Validation Issue Reporting

  • halt(String, Object...) - Reports a fatal validation failure, halting further progress
  • problem(String, Object...) - Reports a non-fatal validation problem, causing data to be discarded but the process does not halt
  • glitch(String, Object...) - Reports a non-fatal and not very important validation problem where data is compromised but not discarded
  • warning(String, Object...) - Reports an issue that should ideally be corrected but is not fatal or a validation failure
  • problemIf(boolean, String, Object...) - Conditionally reports a problem
  • glitchIf(boolean, String, Object...) - Conditionally reports a glitch
  • warningIf(boolean, String, Object...) - Conditionally reports a warning
The base validator also assists in running other validators (validate(Validator), such as validators from Validatable parent classes. The problem and warning methods make use of the variable argument formatting as defined by Formatter in Problem and Warning. To use this class, you need only implement onValidate().

Example Validator

This is roughly the validation method for Place: 

 public Validator validator( ValidationType type)
 {
     return new BaseValidator()
     {
         protected void onValidate()
         {
             // Ensure the superclass
             validate(Place.super.validator(type));

             // then check for other problems
             problemIf(location() == null, "Location is missing");
             problemIf(isEmpty(name()), "Name is empty");
             problemIf(type() == null, "TimeFormat is missing");
             problemIf(isZero(population()), "Population is missing or zero");
         }
     };
 }
Validation Results

Once validation has occurred, the method isInvalid() can be called to determine if any problems or glitches (which are both are considered invalidating while warnings are not) were broadcast during the (possibly nested) validation process. The state of isInvalid() is used as the return value of Validator.validate() when the validator is used.

Subclasses of BaseValidator may be used to decorate problem reports with additional details by overriding the problem(String, Object...) and warning(String, Object...) methods.

Implementation Note

Validation is a recursive, re-entrant process because validators can call other validators. One possible way to propagate the status of validation would be to have a call chain of validators, each returning its status to the prior level. This method results in a lot of boilerplate code creating and checking status objects. A cleaner option, used here, is to keep thread-local statistics during validation and manage nested re-entry with ReentrancyTracker.

Using a reentrancy tracker, thread-local statistics are reset only on the first entrance of a thread to perform a validation operation. This allows statistics to accumulate during validation so that the final exit can inspect the cumulative results of all sub-validations to see if the whole operation has ended in failure or not.

Status-by-step comments that detail this approach are validate(Listener) below.

Author:
jonathanl (shibo)

      public final boolean validate(Listener listener)
      Validates this object, transmitting issues to the given listener. The listener ValidationIssues is handy for capturing validation messages.
      Specified by:
      validate in interface Validator
      Parameters:
      listener - The listener to transmit problems and warnings to. Note that Listener has convenience methods on it to make composing and sending the messages easier.
      Returns:
      True if the object being validated is valid

    • onValidate

      protected abstract void onValidate()
      This method is implemented by the subclass. It may call validate(Validator) on its superclass, and it must call problemIf(boolean, String, Object...), warningIf(boolean, String, Object...), problem(String, Object...) or warning(String, Object...) if there are any validation issues to report. If the problem methods are not called then the validation is valid.

    • problem

      protected Problem problem(String message, Object... parameters)
      Broadcasts a Problem with the given message

      protected final Problem problemIf(boolean invalid, String message, Object... parameters)
      Broadcasts a Problem with the given message if the invalid parameter is true
      Returns:

      protected final boolean validate(Validator validator)
      Re-enters validation by calling the given validator. Calling the validator's validate(Listener) method directly may result in an inconsistent state.
